name: Anonymous
com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Basically in Russia there were reforms made to the liturgy in the 1600s that brought it into alignment with Greek practices, under the claim that the Greek practice was the ancient tradition and the Russian practices were innovations. These were instituted in a very arbitrary and autocratic manner and produced substantial revolt. Later, modern scholarly analysis demonstrated that the Russian practices were more ancient and that the Greek practices were the innovations. You can read about it here if you want, especially see the section "Validity of the reformist theory":
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Believers

Also of interest regarding Eastern Orthodoxy is that around this same period the Orthodox sold absolution certifices, in which you could pay some amount of money to your bishop and receive a written absolution of sins, for you or someone else, without any repentance required. This was understood of course to be the "ancient tradition." It was supported in the Council of Constantinople (1727) and affirmed by multiple patriarchs. It was condemned later in the 1800s.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indulgence#Eastern_Orthodox_Church

com: The whole problem with the "the communists are complaining about Capitalism on their iPhones" argument is that it is a legitimate argument against many idiot liberals, unphilosophical Marxists, and anarkiddies. However, people who have read Hegel and Marx realize that this is only an apparent contradiction because the truth of the Marxist position has been reduced to Harry Potter level moralism. Marxists see Capitalism as THE great liberation. Before Capitalism there was no proletariat class to being with, no hope for progress, no hope for revolution. Capitalism was a horrific, violent, and beautiful revolt that overthrew thousands of years of hereditary rule. The ideas of Monarchism was so baked into people's ideological worldview that when they looked into the fabric of nature itself they saw kingdoms and principalities staring back at them. The achievements of Capitalism cannot be overstated in this regard as well as many others. Marxists praise Capitalism for overthrowing and destroying anything and everything in the way of its efficiency. What Marx did was by a series of calculations found that Capitalism itself would destroy itself by making itself too efficient for itself to exist. Capitalism, when left to its own devices, would automate itself out of existence. Like an artist who realizes that his art cannot be complete while he is still in the world and kills himself as the final poetic flourish - Dazai style. Communism itself is a continuation and intensification of Capitalism own logic against itself. It's a universalization of the Capitalist principles. In the same way traditional liberal humanism ideally made sovereignty, the traditional right of kings, into a universal and equal principle across all subjects, Communism ideally does the same thing with Capital ownership by turning it into a universal and equal right among all citizens.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14309292
You're comparing economic output by GDP meaning the total market value of all goods produced in a region. Socialism and Communism do not seek to maximize profit but rather focus on things like building long term industrial base, providing for the needs of all its citizens, etc.. That doesn't mean they were inefficient but rather that they have different goals. This is fairly obvious once you think about it for more than a second which is why actual economists avoid comparing these different types of economies on these terms. We could compare Communism to Capitalism on terms that favor Communism as well like % of homes/residences that remain permanently empty, % of homelessness, unemployment rate, literacy rate, cost of medicine, death from preventable disease, income inequality, and a whole load of other factors.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Nazi racial ideology wasn't ever coherent or centralized. Basically there was a gradient of racial belief from the more esoteric Aryan supremacist (there is x% of Aryan heritage in every European nation, but Germany and the Germanics have the highest. Not all ethnic Germans are of Aryan descent and should be viewed as a lower caste) to more nationalistic anti-Bolshevik German supremacy that equated German ethnic heritage to Aryanness. Himmler, Rosenberg etc were on the "esoteric" end of the spectrum, Hitler was somewhere in the middle and more "moderate" Nazis like Goering and Speer were on the opposite end. The racial esoteric end could find Aryans wherever they wanted to see them while the nationalists could make allies out of for example the valiant Russian people oppressed by Judeo-Bolshevism.

Of course this ideology was entirely opportunistic. If they wanted to make allies or recruit from Slavic people, they "found" Aryans living amongst them or recruited nationalists who opposed Bolshevism. On the other hand, they could easily cast Slavs as semihuman barbarians when it was politically opportune. In general though, the Nazi party's view on Slavs early on is ambivalent, viewing them initially as a race closely related to the Germanics akin to the Celts. pre-Barbarossa Nazi sentiment towards Slavs was largely driven by their relation to Bolshevism; Pilsudski and the Poles were positively viewed for defending Europe from Bolshevik invasion (Pilsudski's German language autobiography had a forward written by Herman Goering) and the East Slavs were viewed as oppressed people under the yoke of Judeo Bolshevism. However after the failure of Barbarossa this quickly falls apart when they realize the Russian people are not welcoming the Germans as liberators and face resistance across Eastern and Southern Europe, and Slavs in general are viewed as subhuman with plans to eventually eradicate them or "Germanize" them (Poles and Czechs specifically).

name: Anonymous
sub: Let's talk about Amerindian religious organizations
com:
I'll start with Incan religion, pic is the Vilaoma, often equated to a pope or high pontiff of the Inca state cult of the Sun, superior in rank to any other priest and being only second in command after the emperor. An early report of 1535 refers that while the Emperor was considered the "son of the Sun", the Vilaoma was the "servant or slave of the Sun".
Although, it is reported that at the beginning of Guayna Capac's rule, the position of Vilaoma was removed from office and Guayna Capac personally assumed the role of High priest of the Sun.
However, the name took importance again in the government of Manco Inca, after European contact, this Vilaoma, who like Manco and Paullo, supposedly was one of the hundreds of sons of Guayna Capac, took a leading role in Manco's rebellion, as the chief commander in the siege of Cusco, his real name isn't known, the chronicles speak of him as if Vilaoma was his personal name (making a distinction between the historical title, "the Vilaoma", and the right hand of Manco, Vilaoma), it was common to change names according to the stages of life, so this may be the case here.
Anyways, the name Vilaoma probably derives from the words: "Willay" which means to communicate, probably in relation to the sacred oracles or waka (super important for Incan religion), and his role as royal advisor, and "Oma" may come either from uma or head in Quechua or more probably oma/uma water in Aymara and specifically referring to the still existing province of Omasuyos (meaning water province), an area of intense religiosity in relation to the cult of Tunupa/Wiracocha, and just north of Tiahuanaco, where Manco Inca was supposedly born, and probably why he had more support from representatives of the Collasuyo (one of the 4 main divisions of the kingdom) than anywhere else.
In this drawing, he's seen with a chin adornment and a chacrahinca head insignia, both adornments were very characteristic of Collasuyu ethnic aristocracy.

There were numerous expeditions by Confucian scholars to India after the fall of the Han. That was a period of great pessimism in China, with many surviving works essentially saying that Chinese civilization had failed. So there was an interest at looking towards Indian civilization, which the Chinese were surprised to find had an intellectual tradition as deep as their. But concepts like Boddhisatva, karma, and Dharma had no easy analogue in Chinese culture, so scholars had to go to India for texts to translate into Chinese.

This would lead to the uniquely Chinese schools of Buddhism, particularly Chan and Purelander.

Knowing that if he does not answer duty's call, disgrace and shame will be his.
Returning he rides into the siege on a white charger,

name: Anonymous
sub: When and why do some countries experience secession movements?
com: What causes civil wars? Why do people try to split from a nation? Why do countries seek to stop it from happening if the two sides simply can't agree?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14310223
>What causes civil wars?
Mutually exclusive interests among the politically involved, usually with a low simmering tension until some incident acts like a spark to fuel. Unrest, paranoia, and poor decision making follow on both sides as escalation accelerates.
>Why do people try to split from a nation?
A perception that a region's society and identity are distinct from the larger nation, and that they could achieve better outcomes without being a part of said nation - or simply that they could escape (real or imagined) oppression by splitting away from their oppressors. Sometimes both.
>Why do countries seek to stop it from happening if the two sides simply can't agree?
No war or secessionist movement is truly inevitable. If dramatic and stupid incidents that explode tensions can be avoided and pressures can be effectively managed, the notion that two sides simply can't agree isn't set in stone. A lot of the weirder internal setups among nations - like autonomous areas or confederations or whatever - are a result of letting a nation bend rather than break to prevent these problems.

Oh, and also sometimes the secessionist region has vital resources, or (if allied to a foreign power) would be like a knife to the nation's throat, or is seen as an inherent and historical part of the nation that can't be let go without partly de-legitimizing the state, or any number of motives for preventing secession that range from the reasonable to the unreasonable. Sometimes many of them at once.

Yoshiko Kawashima (川島 芳子, Kawashima Yoshiko, 24 May 1907 – 25 March 1948) was a Qing dynasty princess of the Aisin-Gioro clan.

She was born in the Aisin Gioro clan, the imperial clan of the Manchu-led Qing dynasty. Her birth name was Aisin Gioro Xianyu and her courtesy name was Dongzhen (literally "eastern jewel"). Her Sinicised name was Jin Bihui. She is best known by her Japanese name, Kawashima Yoshiko (川島 芳子), which is read as Chuāndǎo Fāngzǐ in Chinese. In 1925, Yoshiko took the male name Ryōsuke.[1]

She was born Aisin Gioro Xianyu in Beijing in 1907 as the 14th daughter of Shanqi (1866–1922), a Manchu prince of the Aisin Gioro clan, the imperial clan of China's Qing dynasty. Her mother was Lady Janggiya (張佳氏), Shanqi's fourth concubine. Shanqi was a descendant of Hooge, the eldest son of Hong Taiji (the second ruler of the Qing dynasty). Shanqi was also the tenth heir to the Prince Su peerage, one of the 12 "iron-cap" princely peerages of the Qing dynasty.

After the Xinhai Revolution overthrew the Qing dynasty in 1912, Xianyu was given up for adoption in 1915 at the age of eight to her father's friend, Naniwa Kawashima, a Japanese espionage agent and mercenary adventurer. Her stepfather changed her name to "Yoshiko Kawashima" and took her back to Tokyo, Japan to be raised and educated in the Kawashima family house. As a teenage girl, Kawashima was sent to school in Tokyo for an education that included judo and fencing.

Around the time her adoptive family moved to Matsumoto. Kawashima's biological father, Shanqi, died in 1922. As Kawashima's mother had no official identity as Shanqi's concubine, she followed Manchu tradition and committed suicide to join Shanqi in death. At the age of seventeen, her adoptive father raped her and later continued to abuse her.[2]

Hui Muslims of Xi'an and the 1912 Xi'an massacre of Manchus

Xi'an city is a Han city with a Muslim quarter. The Hui Muslims of Xi'an lived in Xi'ans Muslim quarter since at least the start of the Ming dynasty. The people of Xi'an traditionally have not participated in any conflicts during the Qing dynasty. Gansu Hui Muslim Ming loyalists under Mi Layin and Ding Guodong fought against the Qing from 1646-1650. A Manchu banner quarter was established in Xi'an on the site of a former Ming prince's palace after Manchus were relocated from their home to garrison quarters in cities south of the Great Wall.

During the Dungan rebellion of the 1860s, the Hui Muslims of Xi'an were the only Hui in southern Shaanxi who did not join the rebellion. As a result Xi'an never fell to the rebels. Shaanxi Hui rebels outside of Xi'an who redefected back to the Qing were not allowed to go back to Shaanxi so they were resettled in Gansu to live along with Gansu Hui rebels like Ma Anliang who defected back.

However in 1911, the when anti-Qing revolutionaries reached Xi'an in the Xinhai revolution, both the Han and Hui Muslims of Xi'an joined the revolt. As the revolutionaries surrounded the Manchu quarter of Xi'an on three sides, the tens of thousands of Manchus attempted to escape from the fourth side. They found that the Hui Muslims of Xi'an's Muslim quarter blocked the entire fourth side. An orgy of arson, looting, massacre and rape against the Manchu population of Xi'an began.

com:
I used to think that people exaggerated this point quite a bit, but I read about various ancient empires and it turns out that it's pretty common for the roles of King and head Priest to be blended together. For example, they had such a system in ancient Egypt.
Now technically the pope only ruled the Papal states, which were a relatively small portion of Italy, but the thing is he could successfully get the kings of other countries to contribute troops to wars he supported, so his soft power let him indirectly influence troop movements all over Europe and into the middle east. Also Pope Leo Crowned Charlemagne so the pope could appoint emperors. This seems vaguely emperor like to me.

name: Epic.
com: Where is the line Drawn between history and humanities?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Humanities are academic disciplines that study aspects of human society and culture. In the Renaissance, the term contrasted with divinity and referred to what is now called classics, the main area of secular study in universities at the time. Today, the humanities are more frequently defined as any fields of study outside of professional training, mathematics, and the natural and social sciences.[1] They use methods that are primarily critical, or speculative, and have a significant historical element[2]—as distinguished from the mainly empirical approaches of the natural sciences;[2] yet, unlike the sciences, the humanities have no general history.[further explanation needed][3]

The humanities include the studies of foreign languages, history, philosophy, language arts (literature, writing, oratory, rhetoric, poetry, etc.), performing arts (theater, music, dance, etc.), and visual arts (painting, sculpture, photography, filmmaking, etc.); culinary art or cookery is interdisciplinary and may be considered both a humanity and a science. Some definitions of the humanities include law and religion,[4] but these are not universally accepted. Although anthropology, archaeology, geography, linguistics, logic, and sociology share some similarities with the humanities, these are widely considered sciences; similarly economics, finance, and political science are not typically considered humanities
